Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing the link between climate and mammalian faunal dynamics in the early Paleocene record of the San Juan Basin, New Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Testing the link between climate and mammalian
faunal dynamics in the early Paleocene record of the San Juan Basin, New Mexico

by

Thomas Williamson, New Mexico Museum of Natural History Foundation EAR-1325544
Ross Secord, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, EAR-1325612
Daniel Peppe, Baylor University, EAR-1325552

ABSTRACT
The Nacimiento Formation of northwestern New Mexico contains the most complete, diverse, and longest record of early Paleocene mammal evolution known anywhere in the world, spanning from about 65.8 to 62.2 million years ago. The early Paleocene is of particular importance for understanding the evolution of modern ecosystems because it includes the first mammal-dominated ecosystems that appeared immediately following the end-Cretaceous extinction of non-avian dinosaurs. This was a time when the world was warmer than now and the climate appears to have been unstable. This study will test for a relationship between climate and mammalian faunal change in the early Paleocene, and will provide a better understanding of the role climate change played in the establishment of the earliest mammal-dominated ecosystems. This project will test if mammals responded to climate change during this critical interval of time by generating a detailed climate record, including estimates of mean annual temperature and precipitation from leaf-margin and leaf-area analyses of fossil leaves, and from the study of ancient soils. This study will also reconstruct the ancient biomes present at this time and the habitats within those biomes using stable carbon isotopes from mammal teeth, and the types of depositional environments present using sedimentology. These various proxy records will be compared to test for correlations between the mammalian faunal record and changing climate or changing biomes in the early Paleocene. Results from this study should be useful for developing more accurate models for predicting the consequences of climate change.
This project will provide educational and research opportunities for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, including Native American students from New Mexico, which are greatly underrepresented in the sciences, and "at risk" 6-8th grade students from Nebraska. The results of this research will also be incorporated into a permanent museum exhibit at the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most dramatic and interesting periods of earth history was the beginning of the “age of mammals” in the early Paleocene, 66 to 62 million years ago. This is the period of time that follows the extinction of dinosaurs (excluding birds). The large majority of mammals that appear in the fossil record after the extinction of dinosaurs are new species, mostly representing groups not known before this time. Several intervals of rapid change occur through the early Paleocene as new mammal species appear and old ones go extinct. The aim of this project was to explore whether these faunal changes were the result of rapid evolution as new species competed to fill ecological niches vacated by dinosaurs, or if climate change played a role in the mammalian “turnover.” To answer this question we generated a large dataset from fossils in the San Juan Basin of New Mexico, USA. We used stable carbon isotopes in ancient soils and in fossil teeth, and fossil leaves as indicators of climate and environmental change.

We discovered two short-term warming events in the upper part of our geological record. The first of these is associated with mammalian turnover (extinction and origination). The second event was at the end of our fossil record with no fossils occurring above it so it was not possible to determine whether or not it was associated with faunal change. Our results indicate that although some mammalian change was associated with the first warming event, climate through most of the early Paleocene was stable. This suggests that most of the evolutionary change in mammals and plants during this interval was the result of internal factors, such as competition among species, rather than climate. Our results are important for understanding the forces driving evolution and how climate change may affect mammals and plants.

Knowledge of how terrestrial ecosystems evolve and respond to changing climate is of broad interest to the scientific community and to the public. Our work helps to address a long standing debate in biology about whether external (climate) or internal factors drive evolution. It also provides information about how mammals responded to a short-term interval of warming in the late Paleocene, which could be useful for developing models aimed at predicting responses to future climate change.

This project provided support for two graduate students and eight undergraduate students at the University of Nebraska. Both graduate students were supported as research assistants, providing them the opportunity to pursue Master of Science degrees, develop research projects, and acquire the skills necessary to become successful scientists. Both students successfully completed their master’s degrees. This project also provided professional development opportunities to eight undergraduate students. Six of these undergraduate students learned valuable field skills working with our group in the San Juan Basin while four gained valuable laboratory experience. The field, laboratory, and interpersonal skills they learned helped them in their goal to become professional geologists. This project assisted and helped to facilitate the educational goals of three women, two of whom belong to ethnic minorities. It provided field experience, outreach experience, laboratory experience, and/or financial support to these women. In so doing, this project has helped to encourage, educate, and support groups that are underrepresented in the STEM (Science-Technology-Engineering-Mathematics) disciplines.

This project also provided funding for a week long workshop for at-risk middle school students at the University of Nebraska State Museum. The workshop was called “Fossil Teeth – Who’s on the Menu?” It gave an overview of how scientists gather evidence that they use to test ideas and draw conclusions. Although most of these students may not go on to become scientists the workshop introduced the students to the university campus and showed them that they were capable of understanding and working with concepts in science. The workshop aimed to make science and higher education more accessible to these students and pique their interest in pursuing education beyond high school.
